Using chrome's own states method (About Memory tab) and with the same number/kind of tabs opened, chrome is eating 1.13 GB of RAM, and Firefox takes only 216 MB.
I know, I've many extensions on chrome, but the sum of them all is around 320 MBs.

Just because the extensions show their memory in task manager can't get you 100% confidence they are irrelevant.
There could be a lot of things affecting this:
- Side effects of loaded extensions in each of the pages
- The obvious, amount of opened tabs
- The less obvious, like amount of closed tabs
- and also amount of history, bookmarks, and even cookies
- Not to mention size of session-specific history (since browser we opened)
- Does the memory include HTML5 local storage that maube some sites support in certain browser implementation but not another?
- Do the sites include Flash? Is it sure to perform equally in both browsers?

To have a fair comparison, you need to create a new user profile, and perform the same exact steps (including closing tabs or going from one page to another in same tab), without extensions or themes or anything.

Thank you Mohamed Meligy for this nice comment, I've already did a clean comparison between FF and chrome inside a fresh Windows 7 VM , both browsers with new installation with NO EXTENSTIONS at all,  and chrome still eats more ram than FF, see the results below:

new window (no tabs, just after a system restart): 
FF==> 102MB,
Chrome==> 168MB

open 10 tabs: 
FF==> 486MB
Chrome==> 752MB

5 minutes after closing the 10 tabs,
FF==> 131MB
chrome==> 196MB

it's now clear enough to say that Chrome team has made a BIG mistake in recent versions that affects memory consumption, but I have no clue about what specifically is causing this.

I love Chrome, but I'm now forced to get back to FF.

I wouldn't worry about ~ 100 MB RAM difference, not in recent time machines. The other difference you refer to (the jump after 5 minutes) looks like a V8 JavaScript VM thing to me. Looks like a lot of JavaScript objects or so that were later garbage collected. Maybe they have an issue though (which to me is sort-of acceptable). Might be worth bringing it to them.
Firefox 12 and 13 have been doing great stuff recently as well anyway, but you know, Chrome is the new IE5/6. A lot of sites are optimized for pre-approved Chrome standard "proposals".

I agree with you, except for the point of 100 MB.
as you can see, it's not 100 MB, it's around 330mb+ with 10 tabs.
and as you know, we (tech guys) surf usually with around 15 ~ 50 tabs opened, so expect a difference in GB scale, and this can't be acceptable from just a "Browser".

as I said, I love Chrome, but I can't live with this issue no more.
my machine has only 4 GB (Home & work), so this affects the overall performance of my machine too much.
moving to Firefox, I now have enough to play with, taking into consideration that I've only 4 GB to play with.
but when I was using Chrome, I convinced myself that I've only 3 GB or so, cause Chrome:The-king was reserving the rest for his majesty :)

I was more talking about the after-5-min result. I usually run my machine with a client VM taking up to 6 GB of my total 10 GB RAM, and have Chrome open all the time on the host machine with many tabs. Rarely a problem.
Are you using the final release channels of both or some pre-final equivalents?
